A Clinical and Radiological Study of Peroneal Tendon Pathology
Abstract: Background.
The proportion of patients with clinical findings referable to peroneal pathology and magnetic resonance imaging (MRI)–diagnosed peroneal tendon pathology is unknown.
Previous studies have correlated surgical findings with clinical data and preoperative MRI, but there are no published studies that reference clinical examination findings to imaging findings.
Purpose.
To determine the relationship between peroneal tendon pathology as diagnosed by MRI and clinical findings of peroneal tendon pathology.
Methods.
Fifty-six patients who had both MRI evidence of peroneal tendon pathology and an associated clinical examination of the ankle were evaluated over a 3-year period at a tertiary care institution.
Clinical examination criteria included lateral ankle tenderness, dislocation/ snapping, and lateral ankle pain.
A board-certified, fellowship-trained musculoskeletal radiologist confirmed the presence of MRI findings consistent with peroneal tendon pathology.
Results.
Of the 56 patients with positive findings on MRI, 27 patients had an associated positive clinical exam and 29 patients had a negative

A Clinical and Radiological Study of Peroneal Tendon Pathology
Eric Giza, MD, Walter Mak, MD, Stephanie E. Wong, BS, Glade Roper, MD, Valentina Campanelli, MS, and John C. Hunter, MD superior peroneal retinaculum.
The peroneus brevis inserts on the base of the fifth metatarsal and the longus passes plantar to the cuboid to insert on the base of the first metatarsal.
Longitudinal tears of the peroneal tendons can occur indirectly secondary to inversion ankle spain, by overuse, subluxation, laxity, or disruption of the superior peroneal retinaculum.1,2 Natural healing of the clinical exam.
The positive predictive value of MRI for peroneal tendon tears with positive clinical findings was 48% (95% confidence interval = 35% to 61%).
Conclusion.
Patients with MRI findings of peroneal tendon pathology should undergo careful clinical examination, as the positive predictive value of MRI for peroneal tendon pathology with actual clinical findings is low.
This study demonstrates that peroneal tendon tears are often incidental findings on MRI.

A Clinical and Radiological Study of Peroneal Tendon Pathology > Levels of Evidence: > Diagnostic, Level III
Keywords: peroneal tendon tears; MRI; clinical examination

A Clinical and Radiological Study of Peroneal Tendon Pathology > Levels of Evidence: > Diagnostic, Level III
“

A Clinical and Radiological Study of Peroneal Tendon Pathology > While MRI can detect peroneal tendon pathology, the clinical presentation and patient examination confirms the diagnosis and subsequent treatment.” > Introduction
The peroneal tendons are the primary evertors of the foot and ankle and contribute to plantar flexion of the ankle and first ray.1 They originate from the fibula and interosseus membrane.
They course posterior to the fibula and are stabilized by a cartilaginous rim on the distal posterior fibula along with the tendons is difficult because of their relative avascularity distal to their musculotendious junction.

A Clinical and Radiological Study of Peroneal Tendon Pathology > While MRI can detect peroneal tendon pathology, the clinical presentation and patient examination confirms the diagnosis and subsequent treatment.” > Introduction
Patients with peroneal tendon tears frequently present with symptoms of vague lateral ankle pain, and thus can be difficult to diagnose.2,3 Patients present with a range of signs and symptoms, including but not limited to lateral ankle swelling, retrofibular pain and tenderness, and palpable retrofibular DOI: 10.1177/1938640013501544.

A Clinical and Radiological Study of Peroneal Tendon Pathology > While MRI can detect peroneal tendon pathology, the clinical presentation and patient examination confirms the diagnosis and subsequent treatment.” > Introduction > Copyright © 2013 The Author(s) > December 2013Foot & Ankle Specialist418
popping with ankle rotation.3-8 During physical exam, the clinician may elicit tenderness with resisted foot eversion and/or exacerbation of retrofibular pain with plantar/dorsiflexion.
Peroneal tendon tears can be associated with recurrent lateral ankle instability but can also present in the stable ankle.5-7 Dombek et al8 reviewed 40 patients who underwent surgical management of peroneal tendon tears to address longstanding pain.
In 42% of cases, the patients could not recall a specific traumatic event.
On average, patients saw 2 physicians and were given 3.3 alternative diagnoses prior to receiving the correct diagnosis of peroneal tendon tear.
In addition to isolated lateral ankle pain, patients reported swelling, instability, difficulty walking, and clicking.8 In recent years, magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) has become an established modality in the evaluation and detection of tendon injuries in the foot and ankle.
A “C-shaped” appearance of the peroneus brevis tendon enveloping the adjacent peroneus longus tendon, usually seen near the level of the retromalleolar groove of the distal fibula, is a classic MRI finding signifying a peroneus brevis split tear.9(pp2170-2173) Other findings include abnormal contour or caliber of the tendon, concomitant peroneal tenosynovitis, associated ligamentous injuries, and abnormally increased signal within the tendon.
A host of anatomical variants predisposing to peroneus brevis split tears are readily detectable at MRI.10 While MRI can detect peroneal tendon pathology, the clinical presentation and patient examination confirms the diagnosis and subsequent treatment.11 The senior author often encounters patients who are referred with MRI findings of peroneal tendon pathology but have no associated symptoms.
Therefore, in clinical practice, it is uncertain how many patients with MRI findings of peroneal tendon split tears have clinical symptoms referable to these tendons.
Most studies to date have been retrospective studies correlating surgical findings with clinical data.4,8 Several studies have correlated surgical findings with preoperative MRI scans.12-14 However, there are no published studies correlating clinical examination findings with radiological findings.
The primary objective of this study is to assess the relationship between peroneal tendon tears as demonstrated by MRI and the clinical signs and/or symptoms of peroneal tendon pathology.

A Clinical and Radiological Study of Peroneal Tendon Pathology > While MRI can detect peroneal tendon pathology, the clinical presentation and patient examination confirms the diagnosis and subsequent treatment.” > Materials and Methods
Institutional review board approval was granted prior to the start of this study.
Inclusion criteria for this study were patients between the ages of 18 and 65 years from our tertiary care institution who had (a) ankle MRI findings indicating a split tear of the peroneus brevis and/or peroneus longus tendon and (b) formal clinical examination of the same ankle by a board-certified orthopaedic surgeon with subspecialty training in sports medicine and foot and ankle surgery.
Patients with previous surgical intervention of the lateral ankle were excluded.
The principal investigator or sports medicine faculty recorded the clinical examination of each patient.
Patients presenting with at least one of the following signs/symptoms were considered to have a positive clinical exam for peroneal tendon pathology:

A Clinical and Radiological Study of Peroneal Tendon Pathology > While MRI can detect peroneal tendon pathology, the clinical presentation and patient examination confirms the diagnosis and subsequent treatment.” > Materials and Methods
peroneal tenderness/weakness, dislocation/snapping, posterior/lateral ankle pain in the anatomic region of the peroneal tendons.
Concomitant symptoms and findings consistent with other ankle maladies were recorded.
Patients in this study either presented for a clinical examination in the orthopaedic outpatient clinic and were subsequently referred for MRI, or were sent for an ankle MRI by a referring physician prior to the patient’s visit to the orthopaedic outpatient clinic.
Typically, the indication for an MRI for patients in this study was a clinical exam consistent with peroneal tendon pathology; however, patients were commonly referred for a previsit MRI ordered for nonspecific reasons or other foot/ankle complaints (Table 1).

A Clinical and Radiological Study of Peroneal Tendon Pathology > While MRI can detect peroneal tendon pathology, the clinical presentation and patient examination confirms the diagnosis and subsequent treatment.” > Materials and Methods
Routine MRI scanning protocol of the ankle was employed in all cases, with T1-weighted and proton density (PD)–weighted sequences in the coronal plane; PD-weighted sequences with and without fat saturation in the axial plane; and T1-weighted and short tau inversion recovery sequences in the sagittal plane.
Occasionally, a T2-weighted fat-saturated sequence was substituted for a PD-weighted fat-saturated sequence.
The majority of the examinations were performed on a conventional 1.5 T scanner or a dedicated 1.5 T extremity scanner (ONI, GE Healthcare, Waukesha, WI).
A few scans were performed on either a
3
T scanner (Trio, Siemens Healthcare, Erlangen, Germany) or a 0.7 T open MRI unit (Profile, GE Healthcare, Waukesha, WI).
Patients scanned in the

A Clinical and Radiological Study of Peroneal Tendon Pathology > While MRI can detect peroneal tendon pathology, the clinical presentation and patient examination confirms the diagnosis and subsequent treatment.” > Materials and Methods
 | peroneus longus and/or peroneus brevis tendon extended anterior to the plane formed by the posterior margin of the distal fibula on any axial image. Peroneal | tenosynovitis was defined as the presence of fluid signal within the tendon sheath on fluid-sensitive sequences (PD fat saturated or short tau | inversion recovery) in at least 2 planes; the degree of tenosynovitis was not quantified. The positive predictive value (PPV) of the MRI findings of peroneal tendon pathology, using the clinical findings as the standard, was calculated by dividing the number of true positives (positive MRI and positive clinical exam) by the number of true positives plus false positives (all positive MRI scans). A 95% confidence interval was calculated for the PPV.

 | Results
 | Fifty-six patients met the inclusion criteria over a 3-year period (2007-2010). The MRI findings in patients who met the MRI criteria for a peroneal tendon tear are included in Table 3. The majority of the positive MRI scans (54%) demonstrated a peroneus brevis split tear in combination with tenosynovitis. Among the 56 patients with positive MRI scans, clinical examination was consistent with a peroneal tendon tear in 27 patients (Table 4). The remaining 29 patients with positive MRI scans had a clinical exam that was negative for symptoms of peroneal tendon pathology (Table 1). Of these patients, 6 MRIs were requested by the referring primary care doctor without recording any specific clinical findings. The remaining 23 MRIs were performed for a foot/ankle complaint other than peroneal or lateral pain. The PPV of MRI for peroneal tendon tears was 48%, with a 95% confidence interval of 35% to 61%. Figure 1 shows an example of peroneal brevis split tear with dislocation on MRI.
 | Discussion
 | The goal of this study was to determine the relationship between peroneal tendon tears diagnosed by MRI and clinical examination findings. This study found that the PPV of MRI for peroneal tendon tears was 48%. Studies to date have not evaluated the correlation between MRI findings and clinical findings in peroneal tendon tears. A Clinical and Radiological Study of Peroneal Tendon Pathology > While MRI can detect peroneal tendon pathology, the clinical presentation and patient examination confirms the diagnosis and subsequent treatment.” > Materials and Methods > Table 2. > Radiological Magnetic Resonance Imaging Criteria for Peroneal Tendon Tears > December 2013Foot & Ankle Specialist420
tears have investigated the correlation between clinical and surgical findings.4,8 Saxena and cassidy4 prospectively evaluated surgical findings and subsequent clinical progress of 41 patients with 49 peroneal tendon tears.
They found that there was a significant difference neither in postoperative American Orthopedic Foot and Ankle score nor in return to activity among patients with peroneus brevis, peroneus longus, or combined tears as confirmed by surgery.
Recent reports have evaluated the correlation between preoperative MRI and operative findings.12-14 Kuwada12 found that MRI findings are surgically confirmed 83% of the time for tears of ligaments and tendons in the foot and ankle, including Achilles tendon, peroneal tendons, posterior tibial tendon, and collateral ligament tears.
The author reported MRI sensitivity of 57% for peroneal tendon tears, which was lower than that of other tendons and ligaments.

A Clinical and Radiological Study of Peroneal Tendon Pathology > While MRI can detect peroneal tendon pathology, the clinical presentation and patient examination confirms the diagnosis and subsequent treatment.” > Materials and Methods > Table 2. > Radiological Magnetic Resonance Imaging Criteria for Peroneal Tendon Tears > December 2013Foot & Ankle Specialist420
The specificity of MRI for peroneal tendon tears was not reported, which makes it difficult to know how accurately MRI detects true peroneal tendon tears.
In addition, the author concluded that of all ligament and tendon injuries studied, peroneal tendon tears were the most difficult pathology to identify by MRI.
A study of 32 patients by Lamm et al13 determined that an MRI diagnosis of peroneus brevis tear had a 83% sensitivity and a 75% specificity as confirmed by surgery.
The investigators concluded that although MRI is the established method of evaluation of peroneal pathology, MRI does not accurately diagnose peroneal tendon pathology.
They suggested that the anatomic location of the peroneal tendons and intrinsic limitations of MRI may contribute to the low sensitivity and specificity for peroneal tendon injuries.
Park et al14 examined the reliability of MRI findings of peroneal tendinopathy confirmed by surgery.
The sensitivity and specificity of peroneal tendinopathy for the 82 cases was 83.9% and 74.5%, respectively; the PPV was 66.7% and the negative predictive value was 88.4%.
The study concluded that MRI is only useful as a diagnostic tool for peroneal tendinopathy if supplemented by physical examination.

A Clinical and Radiological Study of Peroneal Tendon Pathology > While MRI can detect peroneal tendon pathology, the clinical presentation and patient examination confirms the diagnosis and subsequent treatment.” > Materials and Methods > Table 2. > Radiological Magnetic Resonance Imaging Criteria for Peroneal Tendon Tears > December 2013Foot & Ankle Specialist420
Magnetic resonance imaging is often used for imaging evaluation of peroneal tendon tears, but these studies suggest that MRI may not reliably predict peroneal tendon tears as confirmed at surgery.
The finding of a PPV of 48% demonstrates a poor correlation between MRI findings and clinical peroneal tendon pathology.
This suggests that peroneal tendon tears are often incidental findings on ankle MRI, and that an MRI of the ankle may demonstrate findings consistent with peroneal tendon pathology regardless of the initial clinical indication for the MRI.
The most common peroneal tendon pathology found by MRI in this study

A Clinical and Radiological Study of Peroneal Tendon Pathology > While MRI can detect peroneal tendon pathology, the clinical presentation and patient examination confirms the diagnosis and subsequent treatment.” > Materials and Methods > Figure 1.
was peroneus brevis split tear in combination with tenosynovitis, and there were only 8 patients who met the criteria for an isolated peroneus brevis split tear.
Only 8 of the 56 patients with a positive study did not meet criteria for a peroneus brevis split tear.
These findings are consistent with literature reporting that peroneus brevis tears are more common than peroneus longus tears and also typically coexist with other peroneal and lateral ankle pathologies.13 One limitation of this study is that sensitivity and specificity could not be calculated, as our results were not compared with all ankle MRI scans ordered during the study period.
To calculate sensitivity and specificity, a repeat study including all ankle MRI scans performed during the study period is currently underway.
Another limitation of this study is the heterogeneity in MRI technique.
Although the studies were performed on various scanners of varying field strength and with slight variations in scanning protocol, it was felt that adherence to strict diagnostic criteria for diagnosing tendon tears would be sufficient to minimize the significance of any potential differences in the scans.

A Clinical and Radiological Study of Peroneal Tendon Pathology > While MRI can detect peroneal tendon pathology, the clinical presentation and patient examination confirms the diagnosis and subsequent treatment.” > Conclusion
Magnetic resonance imaging has a low PPV for peroneal tendon injuries.
Therefore, split tears of the peroneus brevis tendon or other imaging findings of peroneal tendon pathology are common incidental findings on ankle MRI.
A patient with an ankle MRI study that is positive for peroneal tendon pathology requires clinical correlation to determine the significance of the MRI finding.
The investigators recommend the use of the criteria found in Table 2 as standard criteria for MRI evaluation of peroneal tendon pathology.
